com.pump.image.gif.lzw

Class LZWOutputStream

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.io.OutputStream
      • com.pump.image.gif.lzw.LZWOutputStream
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Closeable, java.io.Flushable, java.lang.AutoCloseable

    public class LZWOutputStream
extends java.io.OutputStream
    This is encoder analogous to the LZWInputStream.

    This encodes a series of bytes as LZW-compressed data.

    This does not in any way break data out into GIF subblocks; this simply takes several bytes and compresses them.

    This class is based on Jef Poskanzer LZW encoding file, which is based on the LZW encoding of several others who came before him. :) See the source code for scattered references to authors.

    This class took Poskanzer code and adapted it to really take advantage of the OutputStream structure: data is written in small, discrete chunks as you call .write().

    The most novel innovation of this class is the writeFewestBytes() method, which makes a kind of lossy GIF compression possible. This considers several possible values, and if possible it writes the first code in the list that will yield some compression.

      • writeFewestBytes

        public int writeFewestBytes(int[] c,
                            int arrayLength)
                     throws java.io.IOException
        This takes a list of possible values to write and writes the first value in this list that will compress, or the first value in this list if none of the values fit into the current compression codes.

        This introduces a kind of "lossy" compression into GIFs, with which you can pass, for example, 6 very similar colors, and this write the color that will yield a smaller byte array.

        Parameters:
        c - a sorted list of values. The best possible match from this list will be written.
        arrayLength - the length of values we should read from c
        Returns:
        the index that was used
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - if an IO problem occurs.
